title: How to Make Zebra Popcorn

parts.name: Popping the Popcorn on a Stovetop

steps.headline: Preheat your oven to 250 °F (121 °C) and lower the rack.
steps.description: To save time, preheat your oven before you start cooking. If your oven rack has multiple shelf positions, move it down to the lowest option.

steps.headline: Put 5 US tbsp (74 mL) of vegetable oil and 3 unpopped kernels in a pot.
steps.description: Use a large, heavy pot for the best results. Pour the oil in first, then drop in 3 kernels to act as a gauge for the oil’s temperature.

steps.headline: Heat the oil and kernels on medium heat with the lid on the pot.
steps.description: Keep the lid on to trap steam and help the pot heat up faster, as well as protect yourself from hot oil. Wait and listen closely for the first pop! Once all 3 kernels have popped, your oil is hot enough for the rest of the popcorn. A transparent glass lid makes it even easier to see the popcorn’s progress.

steps.headline: Add 1  c (240 mL) of unpopped popcorn kernels to the oil carefully.
steps.description: Slowly pour in the kernels, making sure not to splash the hot oil. Place the lid back on the pot and shake it slightly by the handle to coat the popcorn in oil. Place the lid slightly ajar to let steam escape. Shake the pot occasionally while the popcorn cooks.

steps.headline: Remove the pot from the heat when popping slows.
steps.description: When you hear 2-3 seconds of silence in between kernels popping, it’s time to take the pot off of the heat. Turn off the burner and set the pot aside. Several kernels may continue to pop, so wait a minute before removing the pot lid.

steps.headline: Transfer the popcorn into a bowl and remove any unpopped kernels.
steps.description: You won’t want to bite into 1 of the hard, unpopped “duds” later, so remove them now! Sift through the popcorn and check the bottom of the bowl to find the unpopped kernels, then dispose of them. Be careful with the hot kernels! You may want to let the popcorn cool for a minute before handling it. Use a large bowl so you won't have to worry about spilling the popcorn while you sift.

steps.headline: Microwave 2 bags of unsalted popcorn alternatively.
steps.description: If you want to save some time and effort, you can just use a store-bought packets of unsalted, unbuttered popcorn. Cook them in the microwave according to the instructions on the bag, then measure out 20 cups (5 quarts) of popped popcorn into a large bowl. Most microwavable popcorn bags yield 13 cups per bag, so you'll need to pop 2 bags.

steps.headline: Stir together the sugar, corn syrup, salt, and butter over low heat.
steps.description: Get a clean pot and mix in 1.5 cups (350 mL) of packed light brown sugar, 0.5 cups (120 mL) of corn syrup, 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of table salt, and 1 cup (240 mL) of salted butter. The butter will melt slowly, giving you enough time to mix everything together completely. Use a metal or wooden spoon to mix the ingredients together.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat.
steps.description: Turn up the heat to medium and continue stirring the mixture, scraping the sides of the pot to keep it from sticking. Once the sauce begins to boil, remove the pot from the heat. You can either set the pot on a cool burner or a potholder on the counter.

steps.headline: Stir in the baking soda and vanilla and stir continuously.
steps.description: Carefully add the 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of baking soda and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract to the mixture. These ingredients create a chemical reaction, causing the caramel sauce to foam up and thicken quickly. Keep stirring until the sauce reaches a thicker consistency. Make sure there’s a little extra room in the pot for the caramel to swell and foam up a little. If the mixture comes up to the top, it may overflow by a little bit.

steps.headline: Pour the caramel sauce over the bowl of popped popcorn.
steps.description: Drizzle it evenly over the popcorn, stirring as you pour to distribute it through the bowl. Stir the popcorn with a spatula or wooden spoon to coat as many kernels as possible. Be careful, the caramel will still be hot at this point! Pour the caramel over the popcorn as soon as the baking soda and vanilla have been incorporated, otherwise it will harden and become much more difficult to pour.

steps.headline: Transfer the popcorn to 2 parchment paper-lined baking sheets.
steps.description: Spread the caramel-coated popcorn out in a thin, even layer on each sheet. Make sure the parchment paper comes all the way up to the edges of the baking sheet so you don’t have to clean off any baked-on caramel later.

steps.headline: Bake for 1 hour at 250 °F (121 °C), stirring every 15 minutes.
steps.description: Check on the popcorn’s progress periodically and move it around with a wooden spoon so it doesn’t burn. After 1 hour, the popcorn should be crispy and the caramel should look golden and shiny. When it reaches that point, use oven mitts to take the pans out of the oven and set them out to cool completely before adding the chocolate. If you like your popcorn a little softer, you can shorten the baking time by 10-20 minutes.

steps.headline: Pour each kind of chocolate into separate microwavable bowls.
steps.description: Use 1 bowl for the 0.5 cups (120 mL) of semi-sweet chocolate chips, and another for the  0.5 cups (120 mL) of white chocolate chips. Leave yourself enough room to stir easily.

steps.headline: Melt the 2 chocolates separately using 30-second intervals.
steps.description: Place 1 bowl in the microwave at a time, and cook it on high for 30 seconds. Use a spoon to stir it, and repeat the process until the chocolate is fully melted. Repeat the process for the second bowl of chocolate. Make sure to use a different spoon for stirring each type of chocolate so the colors keep their contrast!

steps.headline: Drizzle the chocolate evenly over the popcorn to create “stripes.” Use spoonfuls at a time to pour the chocolate over the trays of popcorn.
steps.description: Try to make the drizzle as thin as possible to spread the chocolate evenly, and overlap the 2 colors to create the signature zebra stripes. If you want the chocolate drizzle to be extra uniform, you can also use a plastic baggie with 1 tip cut off. Fill the baggie with a spoonful of melted chocolate and use the cut end to drizzle with, like a frosting bag.

steps.headline: Let the chocolate harden before breaking the popcorn into pieces.
steps.description: The chocolate should harden quickly, often within 5-10 minutes. Don’t worry if the chocolate breaks up a bit when you divide the popcorn into pieces. Divide it up, then enjoy! You can store any leftover pieces in an airtight container or ziplock bag for up to 1 week.

Get a clean pot and mix in 1.5 cups (350 mL) of packed light brown sugar, 0.5 cups (120 mL) of corn syrup, 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of table salt, and 1 cup (240 mL) of salted butter. The butter will melt slowly, giving you enough time to mix everything together completely. Use a metal or wooden spoon to mix the ingredients together. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium heat. Turn up the heat to medium and continue stirring the mixture, scraping the sides of the pot to keep it from sticking. Once the sauce begins to boil, remove the pot from the heat. You can either set the pot on a cool burner or a potholder on the counter. Stir in the baking soda and vanilla and stir continuously. Carefully add the 0.5 teaspoons (2.5 ml) of baking soda and 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of vanilla extract to the mixture. Pour the caramel sauce over the bowl of popped popcorn. Drizzle it evenly over the popcorn, stirring as you pour to distribute it through the bowl. Stir the popcorn with a spatula or wooden spoon to coat as many kernels as possible. Be careful, the caramel will still be hot at this point! When it reaches that point, use oven mitts to take the pans out of the oven and set them out to cool completely before adding the chocolate. If you like your popcorn a little softer, you can shorten the baking time by 10-20 minutes. Finishing with Chocolate Zebra Stripes Pour each kind of chocolate into separate microwavable bowls. Use 1 bowl for the 0.5 cups (120 mL) of semi-sweet chocolate chips, and another for the  0.5 cups (120 mL) of white chocolate chips. Leave yourself enough room to stir easily. Use a spoon to stir it, and repeat the process until the chocolate is fully melted. Repeat the process for the second bowl of chocolate.
